channel.title: Alerts: Alerts
channel.description: RSS feed for the Alerts list.

item.title: Bushfire ADVICE for the north west part of Woodridge Estate in Gabbadah in the Shire of Gingin
item.description:
Category: Fire
Alert Summary: A bushfire ADVICE has been issued for people in the north west part of Woodridge Estate in Gabbadah in the Shire of Gingin.
Content:

A bushfire ADVICE has been issued for people in the north west part of Woodridge Estate in Gabbadah in the Shire of Gingin.

Firefighters have worked hard to get the fire that started near the corner of Diamond Island Road and Guilderton Road under control.
There is no threat to lives or homes but there is a lot of smoke in the area. Although there is no immediate danger you need to be aware and keep up to date.
WHAT TO DO:
  • Stay alert and monitor your surroundings.
  • Watch for signs of a bushfire, especially smoke and flames.
  • Check the Fire Danger Rating for your area to help you decide what to do www.fesa.wa.gov.au/firedangerratings.
  • Read through your bushfire survival plan.
  • If you do not have a plan decide what you will do if the situation gets worse.
  • People in bushfire risk areas should continue to prepare their property and family for the upcoming bushfire season.
WHAT TO DO:
  • Be extremely careful when driving through the area.
  • Turn your headlights on and drive slowly.
  • Watch for emergency services personnel and follow their directions.
  • If you cannot see clearly, pull over, keep your headlights and hazard lights on, and wait until the smoke clears.
ROAD CLOSURES:
No roads are closed.
Motorists should avoid the area and be aware of fire and other emergency services personnel working on site.
BUSHFIRE BEHAVIOUR:
The bushfire is contained and but not controlled.

WHAT FIREFIGHTERS ARE DOING:
Thirty career and volunteer Fire and Rescue Service and Bush Fire Service firefighters are on the scene.

The Department of Environment and Conservation fixed wing water bombers are no longer required.

The incident was reported at 11.22am today.

CAUSE:
The fire was caused by lightning.
AGENCY RESPONSIBLE:
Shire of Gingin is managing the fire.
IMPORTANT NUMBERS:
If you have a respiratory condition you should contact your local doctor or call Health Direct on 1800 022 222.
KEEP UP TO DATE:
Visit www.fesa.wa.gov.au, call 1300 657 209 or listen to news bulletins.
The next update will be provided at 11am tomorrow (29 October) unless the situation changes.​
Publication Time: 28/10/2012 3:45 PM

item.title: Bushfire ADVICE for people at or travelling near Glen Ayle Station in the Shire of Wiluna
item.description:
Category: Fire
Alert Summary: A bushfire ADVICE remains for people at or travelling near Glen Ayle Station in the Shire of Wiluna.
Content:

A bushfire ADVICE remains for people at or travelling near Glen Ayle Station in the Shire of Wiluna.

The fire is burning approximately 25 kilometres south west of Glen Ayle Station near Sydney Heads Road and is creating a lot of smoke in the area.

There is no threat to lives or homes. Although there is no immediate danger you need to be aware and keep up to date.

WHAT TO DO:
• Be extremely careful when driving through the area.
• Turn your headlights on and drive slowly.
• Watch for emergency services personnel and follow their directions.
• If you cannot see clearly, pull over, keep your headlights and hazard lights on, and wait until the smoke clears.

ROAD CLOSURES:
No roads are closed.

Motorists should avoid the area and be aware of fire and other emergency services personnel working on site.

BUSHFIRE BEHAVIOUR:
The bushfire is moving slowly in a south westerly direction.

It is out of control and unpredictable.

WHAT FIREFIGHTERS ARE DOING:
Pastoralists are on scene monitoring the fire.

Approximately 200,000 hectares have been burnt.

The incident was reported at 12.00pm on Friday 19 October.

CAUSE:
The fire was caused by lightning.

AGENCY RESPONSIBLE:
Shire of Wiluna is managing the fire.

KEEP UP TO DATE:
Visit www.fesa.wa.gov.au, call 1300 657 209 or listen to news bulletins.

The next update will be provided by 11am tomorrow (29 October) unless the situation changes.​

Publication Time: 28/10/2012 3:07 PM

item.title: Bushfire ADVICE for people travelling on Gunbarrel Highway 30 kilometres north east of Carnegie Old Homestead in the Shire of Wiluna
item.description:
Category: Fire
Alert Summary: A bushfire ADVICE remains for people travelling on Gunbarrel Highway 30 kilometres north east of Carnegie Old Homestead in the Shire of Wiluna.
Content:

A bushfire ADVICE remains for people travelling on Gunbarrel Highway 30 kilometres north east of Carnegie Old Homestead in the Shire of Wiluna.

There is no threat to lives or homes but motorists and travellers are asked to avoid the area.

Although there is no immediate danger you need to be aware and keep up to date.

WHAT TO DO:
• If you are already travelling in the area be extremely careful.
• Turn your headlights on and drive slowly.
• Watch for emergency services personnel and follow their directions.
• If you cannot see clearly, pull over, keep your headlights and hazard lights on, and wait until the smoke clears.

ROAD CLOSURES:
Gunbarrel Highway is closed from Warburton to Carnegie Road, near the Carnegie Old Homestead.

Be aware of fire and other emergency services personnel working on site.

For further details contact the Shire of Wiluna.

BUSHFIRE BEHAVIOUR:
The bushfire is moving slowly in a south westerly direction.

It is out of control and unpredictable.

Small pockets of fire remain in the vicinity of the highway and are creating smoke.

Currently the fire has burnt a total of around 170,000 hectares.

WHAT FIREFIGHTERS ARE DOING:
Pastoralists are on scene.

FESA and the Shire of Wiluna are monitoring the fire.

The incident was reported at 12.26pm on Saturday 20 October.

CAUSE:
The fire was caused by lightning.

AGENCY RESPONSIBLE:
Shire of Wiluna is managing the fire.
KEEP UP TO DATE:
Visit www.fesa.wa.gov.au, call 1300 657 209 or listen to news bulletins.
The next update will be provided by 11am tomorrow (29 October) unless the situation changes.​
Publication Time: 28/10/2012 3:03 PM

item.title: Bushfire ADVICE for Connie Sue Road, 154 kilometers north from Neale Junction, in the Great Victoria Desert in the Shire of Laverton
item.description:
Category: Fire
Alert Summary: A bushfire ADVICE remains for people travelling on or near the Connie Sue Road, 154 kilometres north from Neale Junction, in the Great Victoria Desert in the Shire of Laverton.
Content:

ALERT LEVEL:
A bushfire ADVICE remains for people travelling on or near the Connie Sue Road, 154 kilometres north from Neale Junction, in the Great Victoria Desert in the Shire of Laverton.

The fire is burning on both sides of Connie Sue Road.

There is no threat to lives or homes but motorists and travellers need to be aware. Although there is no immediate danger you need to keep up to date.

WHAT TO DO:
• Be extremely careful when driving through the area.
• Stay alert and monitor your surroundings.
• Turn your headlights on and drive slowly.
• Watch for signs of a bushfire, especially smoke and flames.
• Check the Fire Danger Rating for your area to help you decide what to do www.fesa.wa.gov.au/firedangerratings.
• Read through your bushfire survival plan.
• If you do not have a plan decide what you will do if the situation gets worse.
ROAD CLOSURES:
Connie Sue Road is closed from Warburton to the intersection of Cable Haul Road.
Parts of Neale Junction Road and Serpentine Lakes Road (locally known as Anne Beadell Highway) are also closed until further notice.

Contact the Shire of Laverton for more information.

BUSHFIRE BEHAVIOUR:
The fire has been burning for several weeks and has flared up. It is expected to continue to burn for several days.

WHAT FIREFIGHTERS ARE DOING:
FESA and Shire of Laverton are monitoring the fire.

AGENCY RESPONSIBLE:
The Shire of Laverton is managing the fire.

KEEP UP TO DATE:
Visit www.fesa.wa.gov.au, call 1300 657 209 or listen to news bulletins.

The next update will be provided by 11am tomorrow (Monday, 29 October) unless the situation changes.

Publication Time: 28/10/2012 3:00 PM

item.title: Bushfire ADVICE for people travelling near David Carnegie Road, Hunt Oil Road and the Great Central Road in the northern part of the Shire of Laverton
item.description:
Category: Fire
Alert Summary: A bushfire ADVICE remains for people travelling near the David Carnegie Road, Hunt Oil Road and the Great Central Road in the northern part of the Shire of Laverton.
Content:

ALERT LEVEL:
A bushfire ADVICE remains for people travelling near the David Carnegie Road, Hunt Oil Road and the Great Central Road in the northern part of the Shire of Laverton.

There are several fires burning in remote bushland in the area. The fires are burning:
• On both sides of David Carnegie Road 30 kilometres north of Great Central Road.
• On both sides of Hunt Oil Road 50 kilometres north of Great Central Road.

There is no threat to lives or homes but motorists and travellers need to be aware. Although there is no immediate danger you need to keep up to date.

WHAT TO DO:
• Be extremely careful when driving through the area.
• Stay alert and monitor your surroundings.
• Turn your headlights on and drive slowly.
• Watch for signs of a bushfire, especially smoke and flames.
• Check the Fire Danger Rating for your area to help you decide what to do www.fesa.wa.gov.au/firedangerratings.
• Read through your bushfire survival plan.
• If you do not have a plan decide what you will do if the situation gets worse.
BUSHFIRE BEHAVIOUR:
The fires have been burning for four weeks and are expected to continue to burn for a few days.

WHAT FIREFIGHTERS ARE DOING:
FESA and Shire of Laverton are monitoring the fires.

AGENCY RESPONSIBLE:
The Shire of Laverton is managing the fires.

KEEP UP TO DATE:
Visit www.fesa.wa.gov.au, call 1300 657 209 or listen to news bulletins.

The next update will be provided by 11am tomorrow (Monday, 29 October) unless the situation changes.
Publication Time: 28/10/2012 3:00 PM

item.title: Bushfire ADVICE for the Canning Stock Route in the Shire of Wiluna
item.description:
Category: Fire
Alert Summary: A bushfire ADVICE remains for people travelling along the Canning Stock Route in the Shire of Wiluna.
Content:

A bushfire ADVICE remains for people travelling along the Canning Stock Route in the Shire of Wiluna.

There are a number of fires burning along the Canning Stock Route from Windich Spring to Lake Disappointment.

There is no threat to lives or homes but there is a lot of smoke in the area.

Although there is no immediate danger you need to be aware and keep up to date.

WHAT TO DO:
• Stay alert and monitor your surroundings.
• Watch for signs of a bushfire, especially smoke and flames.
• Check the Fire Danger Rating for your area to help you decide what to do www.fesa.wa.gov.au/firedangerratings
IF DRIVING:
• Be extremely careful when driving through the area.
• Turn your headlights on and drive slowly.
• Watch for emergency services personnel and follow their directions.
• If you cannot see clearly, pull over, keep your headlights and hazard lights on, and wait until the smoke clears.
ROAD CLOSURES:
No roads are closed.

Motorists should avoid the area and be aware of fire and other emergency services personnel working on site.

BUSHFIRE BEHAVIOUR:
The bushfires are moving in a south westerly direction.

They are out of control and unpredictable.

WHAT FIREFIGHTERS ARE DOING:
Pastoralists, Rangers and the Shire of Wiluna are monitoring the fires.

The incident was reported on 21 October.

CAUSE:
The cause of the fires was lightning.

AGENCY RESPONSIBLE:
FESA is managing the fires.

IMPORTANT NUMBERS:
If you have a respiratory condition you should contact your local doctor or call Health Direct on 1800 022 222.

KEEP UP TO DATE:
Visit www.fesa.wa.gov.au, call 1300 657 209 or listen to news bulletins.
The next update will be provided by 11am tomorrow (29 October) unless the situation changes.

Publication Time: 28/10/2012 2:55 PM

item.title: Smoke hazard to motorists travelling on Great Northern Highway and Kidson Track in the Shire of Broome and the Shire of East Pilbara
item.description:
Category: Smoke Hazard
Alert Summary: FESA is warning people to be extremely careful while travelling on Great Northern Highway and Kidson Track in the Shire of Broome and the Shire of East Pilbara as they may be affected by smoke.
Content:
FESA is warning people to be extremely careful while travelling on Great Northern Highway and the Kidson Track in the Shire of Broome and the Shire of East Pilbara as they may be affected by smoke.
Motorists travelling along Great Northern Highway between Pardoo roadhouse and the Roebuck Plains roadhouse, at the intersection of the highway and Broome Road, should take extreme caution driving through smoke and areas of low visibility.

Travellers along the Kidson Track between Pardoo and Wallal Downs Station should also take caution because of smoke.
WHAT TO DO:
• Turn headlights on to make your vehicle more visible to others
• Drive slowly
• Keep a close watch for firefighters and emergency service vehicles on the road
• Always follow any directions given by emergency service personnel
• If you cannot see clearly, turn around and drive to a clear area.
• Pull over to the side of the road, keep vehicle headlights and hazard lights on, and wait until the smoke clears.

ROAD CLOSURES:
No roads are closed.
People with respiratory conditions should contact their local doctor or call Health Direct on 1800 022 222.
Publication Time: 27/10/2012 3:05 PM

item.title: Smoke ALERT for motorists travelling on or near the North West Coastal Highway approximately 30 kilometres south of Whim Creek in the Shire of Roebourne
item.description:
Category: Fire
Alert Summary: A smoke alert has been issued for people travelling on or near the North West Coastal Highway approximately 30 kilometres south of Whim Creek in the Shire of Roebourne.
Content:

A smoke alert has been issued for people travelling on or near the North West Coastal Highway approximately 30 kilometres south of Whim Creek in the Shire of Roebourne.

A number of small fires have been burning in largely inacessible areas in the Shire of Roebourne for several days and smoke is approaching the North West Coastal Highway.

Although there is no threat to lives or homes, FESA is warning motorists to take extreme caution when driving through smoke and areas of low visibility.

WHAT TO DO:
• Turn your headlights on and drive slowly.
• Watch for emergency services personnel and follow their directions.
• If you cannot see clearly, pull over, keep your headlights and hazard lights on, and wait until the smoke clears.
• If you have a respiratory condition and you have been affected by smoke you should contact your local doctor or call Health Direct on 1800 022 222.

ROAD CLOSURES:
No roads are closed.

BUSHFIRE BEHAVIOUR:
The bushfires are small but out of control and unpredictable.

WHAT FIREFIGHTERS ARE DOING:
The Shire of Roebourne is monitoring the fires.

AGENCY RESPONSIBLE:
The Shire of Roebourne is managing the fires.

KEEP UP TO DATE:
Visit www.fesa.wa.gov.au, call 1300 657 209 or listen to news bulletins.

The next update will be provided when the situation changes.

​

Publication Time: 27/10/2012 2:49 PM

item.title: Smoke hazard for people in Karijini National Park in the Shire of Ashburton
item.description:
Category: Smoke Hazard
Alert Summary: The Department of Environment and Conservation (DEC) has issued a smoke alert for people travelling to Karijini National Park, as a result of a bushfire that is burning approximately 20 to 25 kilometres north of Karijini Drive, on the eastern side of Banjima Drive West.
Content:

The Department of Environment and Conservation (DEC) has issued a smoke alert for people travelling to Karijini National Park, as a result of a bushfire that is burning approximately 20 to 25 kilometres north of Karijini Drive, on the eastern side of Banjima Drive West.

There is no threat to lives or homes, but the area is expected to be affected by smoke this afternoon and possibly into the weekend.

Motorists are advised to observe signs and directions, and also to turn on headlights and travel at appropriate speeds in the area as smoke may affect visibility.

Personnel from DEC and the Shire of Ashburton are in attendance.

People with conditions exacerbated by smoke should take precautions in line with their medical advice for these circumstances.

The western gorges in Karijini National park (Weano, Hancock, Knox and Joffre gorges) also remain closed to the public due to heavy rains over the past few nights.​

Publication Time: 26/10/2012 2:04 PM

item.title: Smoke ALERT to motorists travelling on or near the Great Central Road between Laverton and Warburton in the Shire of Laverton
item.description:
Category: Smoke Hazard
Alert Summary: Smoke ALERT to motorists travelling on or near the Great Central Road between Laverton and Warburton in the Shire of Laverton
Content:

A smoke alert has been issued for people travelling on or near Great Central Road between Laverton and Warburton in the Shire of Laverton.

A number of small fires have been caused by lightening and are burning on either side of Great Central Road.

There is no threat to lives or homes but there is a lot of smoke in the area.

FESA is warning motorists travelling along or near Great Central Road to take extreme caution when driving through smoke and areas of low visibility.

WHAT TO DO:
• Be extremely careful when driving through the area.
• Turn your headlights on and drive slowly.
• Watch for emergency services personnel and follow their directions.
• If you cannot see clearly, pull over, keep your headlights and hazard lights on, and wait until the smoke clears.
• If you have a respiratory condition and you have been affected by smoke you should contact your local doctor or call Health Direct on 1800 022 222.

ROAD CLOSURES:
No roads are closed.

BUSHFIRE BEHAVIOUR:
The fires are slow moving and controllable.

WHAT FIREFIGHTERS ARE DOING:
FESA, Shire of Laverton, local Indigenous communities and nearby exploration/mining companies are monitoring the fires.

AGENCY RESPONSIBLE:
The Shire of Laverton managing the fire.

KEEP UP TO DATE:
Visit www.fesa.wa.gov.au, call 1300 657 209 or listen to news bulletins.

The next update will be provided when the situation changes.
​

Publication Time: 26/10/2012 10:52 AM
